Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
At about six o'clock in the morning
on September 14, 2015, scientists witnessed something
no human had ever seen: two black holes colliding. Both about 30 times as massive
as our Sun, they had been orbiting each other
for millions of years. As they got closer together, they circled each other faster and faster. Finally, they collided and merged
into a single, even bigger, black hole. A fraction of a second before their crash, they sent a vibration across the universe
at the speed of light. And on Earth, billions of years later, a detector called the Laser Interferometer
Gravitational Wave Observatory, or LIGO for short, picked it up. The signal only lasted a fifth of a second and was the detector's first observation
of gravitational waves. What are these ripples in space? The answer starts with gravity, the force that pulls any 
two objects together. That's the case for everything
In the observable universe. You're pulling on the Earth,
the Moon, the Sun, and every single star, and they're pulling on you. The more mass something has,
the stronger its gravitational pull. The farther away the object,
the lower its pull. If every mass has an effect
on every other mass in the universe, no matter how small, then changes in gravity can tell us
about what those objects are doing. Fluctuations in the gravity
coming from the universe are called gravitational waves. Gravitational waves move out from 
what caused them, like ripples on a pond, getting smaller as they travel farther
from their center. But what are they ripples on? When Einstein devised 
his Theory of Relativity, he imagined gravity as a curve
in a surface called space-time. A mass in space creates a depression
in space-time, and a ball rolling across a depression
will curve like it's being attracted 
to the other mass. The bigger the mass, the deeper the depression
and the stronger the gravity. When the mass making the depression moves,
that sends out ripples in space-time. These are gravitationl waves. What would a gravitational wave feel like? If our bodies were sensitive enough
to detect them, we'd feel like we were 
being stretched sideways while being compressed vertically. And in the next instant, stretched up and down 
while being compressed horizontally, sideways, then up and down. This back and forth would happen
over and over as the gravitational wave
passed right through you. But this happens on such a minute scale
that we can't feel any of it. So we've built detectors 
that can feel it for us. That's what the LIGO detectors do. And they're not the only ones. There are gravitational wave detectors
spread across the world. These L-shaped instruments have long arms, whose exact length 
is measured with lasers. If the length changes, it could be because
gravitational waves are stretching and compressing the arms. Once the detectors feel 
a gravitational wave, scientists can extract information
about the wave's source. In a way, detectors like LIGO are
big gravitational wave radios. Radio waves are traveling all around you,
but you can't feel them or hear the music they carry. It takes the right kind of 
detector to extract the music. LIGO detects a gravitational wave signal, which scientists then study for data
about the object that generated it. They can derive information, 
like its mass and the shape of its orbit. We can also hear gravitational waves
by playing their signals through speakers, just like the music a radio extracts
from radio waves. So those two black holes colliding
sounds like this. Scientists call this 
slide whistle-like noise a chirp, and it's the signature of any two
objects orbiting into each other. The black hole collision 
was just one example of what gravitational waves can tell us. Other high-energy astronomical events
will leave gravitational echoes, too. The collapse of a star before it
explodes in a supernova, or a very dense neutron stars colliding. Every time we create a new tool
to look at space, we discover something we didn't expect, something that might revolutionize
our understanding of the universe. LIGO's no different. In the short time it's been on, LIGO's already revealed surprises, like that black holes collide
more often than we ever expected. It's impossible to say, 
but exciting to imagine, what revelations may now be propagating
across space towards our tiny blue planet and
its new way of perceiving the universe.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: If a gravitational wave was strong enough for you to feel, what would it feel like?
Options: A. Like hot and cold flashes, B. Like a tingling sensation, C. Like being stretched in one direction and compressed in another, D. Like being twisted back and forth
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Every year, about 1,000 new words are
added to the Oxford English Dictionary. Where do they come from, and how do they make it 
into our everyday lives? With over 170,000 words currently in use
in the English language, it might seem we already have plenty. Yet, as our world changes, new ideas and inventions spring forth, and science progresses, our existing words leave gaps
in what we want to express and we fill those gaps 
in several ingenious, practical, and occasionally peculiar ways. One way is to absorb a word
from another language. English has borrowed so many words
over its history that nearly half of its vocabulary 
comes directly from other languages. Sometimes, this is simply because
the thing the word describes was borrowed itself. Rome and France brought legal
and religious concepts, like altar and jury, to Medieval England, while trade brought crops and cuisine, like Arabic coffee, Italian spaghetti, and Indian curry. But sometimes, another language 
has just the right word for a complex idea or emotion, like naïveté machismo, or schadenfreude. Scientists also use classical languages
to name new concepts. Clone, for example, was derived from
the Ancient Greek word for twig to describe creating a new plant
from a piece of the old. And today, the process works both ways, with English lending words like software
to languages all over the world. Another popular way 
to fill a vocabulary gap is by combining existing words that each
convey part of the new concept. This can be done by combining two
whole words into a compound word, like airport or starfish, or by clipping and blending parts of words
together, like spork, brunch, or internet. And unlike borrowings 
from other languages, these can often be understood
the first time you hear them. And sometimes a new word isn't new at all. Obsolete words gain new life by adopting
new meanings. Villain originally meant a peasant farmer,
but in a twist of aristocratic snobbery came to mean someone not bound
by the knightly code of chivalry and, therefore, a bad person. A geek went from 
being a carnival performer to any strange person to a specific type of awkward genius. And other times, words come to mean
their opposite through irony, metaphor, or misuse, like when sick or wicked are used
to describe something literally amazing. But if words can be formed 
in all these ways, why do some become mainstream
while others fall out of use or never catch on in the first place? Sometimes, the answer is simple, as when scientists or companies 
give an official name to a new discovery or technology. And some countries have language academies
to make the decisions. But for the most part, official sources
like dictionaries only document current usage. New words don't originate from above,
but from ordinary people spreading words that 
hit the right combination of useful and catchy. Take the word meme, coined in the 1970s 
by sociobiologist Richard Dawkins from the Ancient Greek for imitation. He used it to describe how ideas
and symbols propagate through a culture like genes through a population. With the advent of the Internet, the process became directly observable
in how jokes and images were popularized at lightning speed. And soon, the word came to refer
to a certain kind of image. So meme not only describes how words
become part of language, the word is a meme itself. And there's a word for this phenomenon
of words that describe themselves: autological. Not all new words are created equal. Some stick around for millennia, some adapt to changing times, and others die off. Some relay information, some interpret it, but the way these words are created and the journey they take to become
part of our speech tells us a lot about our world
and how we communicate within it.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: One way a word enters a language is by:
Options: A. Borrowing it from another language, B. Cloning an existing word, C. Luck, D. Eliminating another word
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Approximately how many t-shirts are sold and bought globally each year? Options: A. 1 billion, B. 2 billion, C. 5 billion, D. 10 billion Correct Option: B
Question 2: Where does the average t-shirt begin its life? Options: A. In a textile mill, B. On a farm in America, China, or India, C. In a factory in Bangladesh, D. In a recycling center Correct Option: B
Question 3: How many liters of water are needed to produce the average t-shirt? Options: A. 1,000 liters, B. 2,700 liters, C. 5,000 liters, D. 10,000 liters Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is a significant environmental impact of cotton production? Options: A. Cotton requires a lot of water, but not pesticides., B. Cotton uses more insecticides and pesticides than any other crop in the world., C. Cotton is a sustainable crop that does not harm the environment., D. Cotton is a crop that only grows in high-income countries. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is a potential health risk associated with some t-shirts? Options: A. They can cause skin irritation., B. They can contain cancer-causing cadmium, lead, chromium, and mercury., C. They can cause respiratory problems., D. They can cause eye problems. Correct Option: B
Question 6: How can consumers reduce the environmental impact of t-shirt production? Options: A. By buying more t-shirts., B. By shopping secondhand., C. By looking for textiles made from recycled or organic fabrics., D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is a significant problem associated with the t-shirt industry in Bangladesh? Options: A. Workers are paid high wages., B. Workers face poor conditions and low wages., C. The industry is highly regulated., D. The industry is not significant. Correct Option: B
Question 8: What contributes to the environmental impact of t-shirt production? Options: A. Only the production process itself., B. Only the transportation of t-shirts to high-income countries., C. Only the disposal of t-shirts at the end of their life., D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 9: How can consumers reduce the environmental impact of t-shirt consumption? Options: A. By washing clothes more frequently., B. By line drying clothes instead of using a dryer., C. By donating, recycling, or reusing old t-shirts., D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is a significant consequence of the trend of fast fashion? Options: A. It has increased the demand for sustainable clothing., B. It has reduced the environmental impact of clothing production., C. It has turned fashion into the second-largest polluter in the world., D. It has had no impact on the environment. Correct Option: C
Question 11: Approximately how many t-shirts are produced globally each year? Options: A. 50 billion, B. 80 billion, C. 100 billion, D. 120 billion Correct Option: B
Question 12: What percentage of global carbon emissions is attributed to apparel production? Options: A. 5%, B. 10%, C. 15%, D. 20% Correct Option: B
Question 13: What is a significant environmental impact of washing and drying clothes? Options: A. They require a lot of energy., B. They use a lot of water., C. They produce a lot of waste., D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 14: How can consumers reduce the environmental impact of their laundry? Options: A. By washing clothes less frequently., B. By line drying clothes instead of using a dryer., C. By using a washing machine with a high water consumption., D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 15: What is a significant resource-intensive phase of a t-shirt's lifetime? Options: A. The production process, B. Transportation process, C. Consumption process, D. Disposal process Correct Option: C
Question 16: Approximately how many loads of laundry does the average household do in a year? Options: A. 100 loads, B. 200 loads, C. 300 loads, D. 400 loads Correct Option: D
Question 17: How much water does the average household use for laundry in a year? Options: A. 10,000 gallons, B. 20,000 gallons, C. 30,000 gallons, D. 40,000 gallons Correct Option: D
Question 18: How much energy does a dryer use compared to a washing machine? Options: A. 1-2 times more, B. 3-4 times more, C. 5-6 times more, D. 7-8 times more Correct Option: C
Question 19: What is a significant benefit of shopping secondhand? Options: A. It saves money, B. It reduces the demand for new clothing, C. It reduces the environmental impact of clothing production, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 20: What is a significant impact of the trend of fast fashion on the environment? Options: A. It has increased the demand for sustainable clothing, B. It has reduced the environmental impact of clothing production, C. It has turned fashion into the second-largest polluter in the world, D. It has had no impact on the environment Correct Option: C

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Every year, about 1,000 new words are
added to the Oxford English Dictionary. Where do they come from, and how do they make it 
into our everyday lives? With over 170,000 words currently in use
in the English language, it might seem we already have plenty. Yet, as our world changes, new ideas and inventions spring forth, and science progresses, our existing words leave gaps
in what we want to express and we fill those gaps 
in several ingenious, practical, and occasionally peculiar ways. One way is to absorb a word
from another language. English has borrowed so many words
over its history that nearly half of its vocabulary 
comes directly from other languages. Sometimes, this is simply because
the thing the word describes was borrowed itself. Rome and France brought legal
and religious concepts, like altar and jury, to Medieval England, while trade brought crops and cuisine, like Arabic coffee, Italian spaghetti, and Indian curry. But sometimes, another language 
has just the right word for a complex idea or emotion, like naïveté machismo, or schadenfreude. Scientists also use classical languages
to name new concepts. Clone, for example, was derived from
the Ancient Greek word for twig to describe creating a new plant
from a piece of the old. And today, the process works both ways, with English lending words like software
to languages all over the world. Another popular way 
to fill a vocabulary gap is by combining existing words that each
convey part of the new concept. This can be done by combining two
whole words into a compound word, like airport or starfish, or by clipping and blending parts of words
together, like spork, brunch, or internet. And unlike borrowings 
from other languages, these can often be understood
the first time you hear them. And sometimes a new word isn't new at all. Obsolete words gain new life by adopting
new meanings. Villain originally meant a peasant farmer,
but in a twist of aristocratic snobbery came to mean someone not bound
by the knightly code of chivalry and, therefore, a bad person. A geek went from 
being a carnival performer to any strange person to a specific type of awkward genius. And other times, words come to mean
their opposite through irony, metaphor, or misuse, like when sick or wicked are used
to describe something literally amazing. But if words can be formed 
in all these ways, why do some become mainstream
while others fall out of use or never catch on in the first place? Sometimes, the answer is simple, as when scientists or companies 
give an official name to a new discovery or technology. And some countries have language academies
to make the decisions. But for the most part, official sources
like dictionaries only document current usage. New words don't originate from above,
but from ordinary people spreading words that 
hit the right combination of useful and catchy. Take the word meme, coined in the 1970s 
by sociobiologist Richard Dawkins from the Ancient Greek for imitation. He used it to describe how ideas
and symbols propagate through a culture like genes through a population. With the advent of the Internet, the process became directly observable
in how jokes and images were popularized at lightning speed. And soon, the word came to refer
to a certain kind of image. So meme not only describes how words
become part of language, the word is a meme itself. And there's a word for this phenomenon
of words that describe themselves: autological. Not all new words are created equal. Some stick around for millennia, some adapt to changing times, and others die off. Some relay information, some interpret it, but the way these words are created and the journey they take to become
part of our speech tells us a lot about our world
and how we communicate within it.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: A way to fill-in a conceptual gap in a language is to:
Options: A. Ignore it, B. Combine existing words, C. Look up a new word, D. Guess
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Approximately how many t-shirts are sold and bought globally each year? Options: A. 1 billion, B. 2 billion, C. 5 billion, D. 10 billion Correct Option: B
Question 2: Where does the average t-shirt begin its life? Options: A. In a textile mill, B. On a farm in America, China, or India, C. In a factory in Bangladesh, D. In a recycling center Correct Option: B
Question 3: How many liters of water are needed to produce the average t-shirt? Options: A. 1,000 liters, B. 2,700 liters, C. 5,000 liters, D. 10,000 liters Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is a significant environmental impact of cotton production? Options: A. Cotton requires a lot of water, but not pesticides., B. Cotton uses more insecticides and pesticides than any other crop in the world., C. Cotton is a sustainable crop that does not harm the environment., D. Cotton is a crop that only grows in high-income countries. Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is a potential health risk associated with some t-shirts? Options: A. They can cause skin irritation., B. They can contain cancer-causing cadmium, lead, chromium, and mercury., C. They can cause respiratory problems., D. They can cause eye problems. Correct Option: B
Question 6: How can consumers reduce the environmental impact of t-shirt production? Options: A. By buying more t-shirts., B. By shopping secondhand., C. By looking for textiles made from recycled or organic fabrics., D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is a significant problem associated with the t-shirt industry in Bangladesh? Options: A. Workers are paid high wages., B. Workers face poor conditions and low wages., C. The industry is highly regulated., D. The industry is not significant. Correct Option: B
Question 8: What contributes to the environmental impact of t-shirt production? Options: A. Only the production process itself., B. Only the transportation of t-shirts to high-income countries., C. Only the disposal of t-shirts at the end of their life., D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 9: How can consumers reduce the environmental impact of t-shirt consumption? Options: A. By washing clothes more frequently., B. By line drying clothes instead of using a dryer., C. By donating, recycling, or reusing old t-shirts., D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 10: What is a significant consequence of the trend of fast fashion? Options: A. It has increased the demand for sustainable clothing., B. It has reduced the environmental impact of clothing production., C. It has turned fashion into the second-largest polluter in the world., D. It has had no impact on the environment. Correct Option: C
Question 11: Approximately how many t-shirts are produced globally each year? Options: A. 50 billion, B. 80 billion, C. 100 billion, D. 120 billion Correct Option: B
Question 12: What percentage of global carbon emissions is attributed to apparel production? Options: A. 5%, B. 10%, C. 15%, D. 20% Correct Option: B
Question 13: What is a significant environmental impact of washing and drying clothes? Options: A. They require a lot of energy., B. They use a lot of water., C. They produce a lot of waste., D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 14: How can consumers reduce the environmental impact of their laundry? Options: A. By washing clothes less frequently., B. By line drying clothes instead of using a dryer., C. By using a washing machine with a high water consumption., D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 15: What is a significant resource-intensive phase of a t-shirt's lifetime? Options: A. The production process, B. Transportation process, C. Consumption process, D. Disposal process Correct Option: C
Question 16: Approximately how many loads of laundry does the average household do in a year? Options: A. 100 loads, B. 200 loads, C. 300 loads, D. 400 loads Correct Option: D
Question 17: How much water does the average household use for laundry in a year? Options: A. 10,000 gallons, B. 20,000 gallons, C. 30,000 gallons, D. 40,000 gallons Correct Option: D
Question 18: How much energy does a dryer use compared to a washing machine? Options: A. 1-2 times more, B. 3-4 times more, C. 5-6 times more, D. 7-8 times more Correct Option: C
Question 19: What is a significant benefit of shopping secondhand? Options: A. It saves money, B. It reduces the demand for new clothing, C. It reduces the environmental impact of clothing production, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 20: What is a significant impact of the trend of fast fashion on the environment? Options: A. It has increased the demand for sustainable clothing, B. It has reduced the environmental impact of clothing production, C. It has turned fashion into the second-largest polluter in the world, D. It has had no impact on the environment Correct Option: C

**Transcript**:
Every year, about 1,000 new words are
added to the Oxford English Dictionary. Where do they come from, and how do they make it 
into our everyday lives? With over 170,000 words currently in use
in the English language, it might seem we already have plenty. Yet, as our world changes, new ideas and inventions spring forth, and science progresses, our existing words leave gaps
in what we want to express and we fill those gaps 
in several ingenious, practical, and occasionally peculiar ways. One way is to absorb a word
from another language. English has borrowed so many words
over its history that nearly half of its vocabulary 
comes directly from other languages. Sometimes, this is simply because
the thing the word describes was borrowed itself. Rome and France brought legal
and religious concepts, like altar and jury, to Medieval England, while trade brought crops and cuisine, like Arabic coffee, Italian spaghetti, and Indian curry. But sometimes, another language 
has just the right word for a complex idea or emotion, like naïveté machismo, or schadenfreude. Scientists also use classical languages
to name new concepts. Clone, for example, was derived from
the Ancient Greek word for twig to describe creating a new plant
from a piece of the old. And today, the process works both ways, with English lending words like software
to languages all over the world. Another popular way 
to fill a vocabulary gap is by combining existing words that each
convey part of the new concept. This can be done by combining two
whole words into a compound word, like airport or starfish, or by clipping and blending parts of words
together, like spork, brunch, or internet. And unlike borrowings 
from other languages, these can often be understood
the first time you hear them. And sometimes a new word isn't new at all. Obsolete words gain new life by adopting
new meanings. Villain originally meant a peasant farmer,
but in a twist of aristocratic snobbery came to mean someone not bound
by the knightly code of chivalry and, therefore, a bad person. A geek went from 
being a carnival performer to any strange person to a specific type of awkward genius. And other times, words come to mean
their opposite through irony, metaphor, or misuse, like when sick or wicked are used
to describe something literally amazing. But if words can be formed 
in all these ways, why do some become mainstream
while others fall out of use or never catch on in the first place? Sometimes, the answer is simple, as when scientists or companies 
give an official name to a new discovery or technology. And some countries have language academies
to make the decisions. But for the most part, official sources
like dictionaries only document current usage. New words don't originate from above,
but from ordinary people spreading words that 
hit the right combination of useful and catchy. Take the word meme, coined in the 1970s 
by sociobiologist Richard Dawkins from the Ancient Greek for imitation. He used it to describe how ideas
and symbols propagate through a culture like genes through a population. With the advent of the Internet, the process became directly observable
in how jokes and images were popularized at lightning speed. And soon, the word came to refer
to a certain kind of image. So meme not only describes how words
become part of language, the word is a meme itself. And there's a word for this phenomenon
of words that describe themselves: autological. Not all new words are created equal. Some stick around for millennia, some adapt to changing times, and others die off. Some relay information, some interpret it, but the way these words are created and the journey they take to become
part of our speech tells us a lot about our world
and how we communicate within it.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. Analogy with the word gene, B. Borrowing from another language, C. A dictionary look-up process, D. Speculation
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Every year, about 1,000 new words are
added to the Oxford English Dictionary. Where do they come from, and how do they make it 
into our everyday lives? With over 170,000 words currently in use
in the English language, it might seem we already have plenty. Yet, as our world changes, new ideas and inventions spring forth, and science progresses, our existing words leave gaps
in what we want to express and we fill those gaps 
in several ingenious, practical, and occasionally peculiar ways. One way is to absorb a word
from another language. English has borrowed so many words
over its history that nearly half of its vocabulary 
comes directly from other languages. Sometimes, this is simply because
the thing the word describes was borrowed itself. Rome and France brought legal
and religious concepts, like altar and jury, to Medieval England, while trade brought crops and cuisine, like Arabic coffee, Italian spaghetti, and Indian curry. But sometimes, another language 
has just the right word for a complex idea or emotion, like naïveté machismo, or schadenfreude. Scientists also use classical languages
to name new concepts. Clone, for example, was derived from
the Ancient Greek word for twig to describe creating a new plant
from a piece of the old. And today, the process works both ways, with English lending words like software
to languages all over the world. Another popular way 
to fill a vocabulary gap is by combining existing words that each
convey part of the new concept. This can be done by combining two
whole words into a compound word, like airport or starfish, or by clipping and blending parts of words
together, like spork, brunch, or internet. And unlike borrowings 
from other languages, these can often be understood
the first time you hear them. And sometimes a new word isn't new at all. Obsolete words gain new life by adopting
new meanings. Villain originally meant a peasant farmer,
but in a twist of aristocratic snobbery came to mean someone not bound
by the knightly code of chivalry and, therefore, a bad person. A geek went from 
being a carnival performer to any strange person to a specific type of awkward genius. And other times, words come to mean
their opposite through irony, metaphor, or misuse, like when sick or wicked are used
to describe something literally amazing. But if words can be formed 
in all these ways, why do some become mainstream
while others fall out of use or never catch on in the first place? Sometimes, the answer is simple, as when scientists or companies 
give an official name to a new discovery or technology. And some countries have language academies
to make the decisions. But for the most part, official sources
like dictionaries only document current usage. New words don't originate from above,
but from ordinary people spreading words that 
hit the right combination of useful and catchy. Take the word meme, coined in the 1970s 
by sociobiologist Richard Dawkins from the Ancient Greek for imitation. He used it to describe how ideas
and symbols propagate through a culture like genes through a population. With the advent of the Internet, the process became directly observable
in how jokes and images were popularized at lightning speed. And soon, the word came to refer
to a certain kind of image. So meme not only describes how words
become part of language, the word is a meme itself. And there's a word for this phenomenon
of words that describe themselves: autological. Not all new words are created equal. Some stick around for millennia, some adapt to changing times, and others die off. Some relay information, some interpret it, but the way these words are created and the journey they take to become
part of our speech tells us a lot about our world
and how we communicate within it.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Obsolete words can gain new life:
Options: A. Because of nostalgia, B. Through a whim, C. By legislation, D. By giving them new meanings
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Consider the classic white t-shirt. Annually, we sell and buy
two billion t-shirts globally, making it one of the most common
garments in the world. But how and where is the average
t-shirt made, and what's its environmental impact? Clothing items can vary a lot, but a typical t-shirt begins its life
on a farm in America, China, or India where cotton seeds are sown, irrigated and
grown for the fluffy bolls they produce. Self-driving machines carefully harvest
these puffs, an industrial cotton gin mechanically
separates the fluffy bolls from the seeds, and the cotton lint is pressed 
into 225-kilogram bales. The cotton plants require a huge quantity
of water and pesticides. 2,700 liters of water are needed to produce
the average t-shirt, enough to fill more than 30 bathtubs. Meanwhile, cotton uses more insecticides
and pesticides than any other crop in the world. These pollutants can be carcinogenic, harm the health of field workers, and damage surrounding ecosystems. Some t-shirts are made of organic cotton
grown without pesticides and insecticides, but organic cotton makes up less than 1% of the 22.7 million metric tons 
of cotton produced worldwide. Once the cotton bales leave the farm, textile mills ship them
to a spinning facility, usually in China or India, where high-tech machines blend, card, comb, pull, stretch, and, finally, twist the cotton into
snowy ropes of yarn called slivers. Then, yarns are sent to the mill, where huge circular knitting machines weave them into sheets 
of rough grayish fabric treated with heat and chemicals
until they turn soft and white. Here, the fabric is dipped into
commercial bleaches and azo dyes, which make up the vivid coloring
in about 70% of textiles. Unfortunately, some of these contain
cancer-causing cadmium, lead, chromium, and mercury. Other harmful compounds and chemicals
can cause widespread contamination when released as toxic waste water
in rivers and oceans. Technologies are now so advanced
in some countries that the entire process of growing
and producing fabric barely touches a human hand. But only up until this point. After the finished cloth 
travels to factories, often in Bangladesh, China, India,
or Turkey, human labor is still required 
to stitch them up into t-shirts, intricate work that 
machines just can't do. This process has its own problems. Bangladesh, for example, which has surpassed China as the world's
biggest exporter of cotton t-shirts, employs 4.5 million people
in the t-shirt industry, but they typically face poor conditions
and low wages. After manufacture, all those t-shirts
travel by ship, train, and truck to be sold in high-income countries, a process that gives cotton 
an enormous carbon footprint. Some countries produce 
their own clothing domestically, which cuts out this polluting stage, but generally, apparel production accounts
for 10% of global carbon emissions. And it's escalating. Cheaper garments and the public's
willingness to buy boosted global production 
from 1994 to 2014 by 400% to around 80 billion garments each year. Finally, in a consumer's home, the t-shirt goes through one of the most
resource-intensive phases of its lifetime. In America, for instance, the average household does nearly
400 loads of laundry per year each using about 40 gallons of water. Washing machines and dryers 
both use energy, with dryers requiring five to six times
more than washers. This dramatic shift in clothing 
consumption over the last 20 years, driven by large corporations
and the trend of fast fashion has cost the environment, the health of farmers, and driven questionable 
human labor practices. It's also turned fashion into the second
largest polluter in the world after oil. But there are things we can do. Consider shopping secondhand. Try to look for textiles made from
recycled or organic fabrics. Wash clothes less and line dry
to save resources. Instead of throwing them away
at the end of their life, donate, recycle, or reuse them
as cleaning rags. And, finally, you might ask yourself, how many t-shirts and articles of clothing
will you consume over your lifetime, and what will be their combined 
impact on the world?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Where in the world is cotton commonly grown?
Options: A. India, B. China, C. America, D. A and b only, E. All of the above
Correct Option: E

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the reason for Psyche's abandonment by her father? Options: A. He was worried about her beauty attracting unwanted attention., B. He was asked by the Oracle of Apollo to abandon his daughter., C. He was jealous of her relationship with Cupid., D. He was instructed by the gods to abandon her. Correct Option: B
Question 2: What was the first task set by Venus for Psyche to complete? Options: A. To bring back the fleece of the golden sheep., B. To sort a huge pile of seeds., C. To convince Proserpina to put a drop of her beauty in a box., D. To travel to the Underworld and collect a box from Proserpina. Correct Option: B
Question 3: Who helped Psyche with the task of sorting the seeds? Options: A. Cupid., B. The Oracle of Apollo., C. An ant colony., D. Zephyr the West Wind. Correct Option: C
Question 4: What was the river god who showed Psyche how to collect the fleece of the golden sheep? Options: A. Zephyr., B. Charon., C. The Oracle of Apollo., D. Not mentioned in the transcript. Correct Option: D
Question 5: What was the final task set by Venus for Psyche to complete? Options: A. To travel to the Underworld and convince Proserpina to put a drop of her beauty in a box., B. To sort a huge pile of seeds., C. To bring back the fleece of the golden sheep., D. To collect a box from Proserpina. Correct Option: A
Question 6: What was the purpose of the barley cakes and coins given to Cerberus and Charon by Psyche? Options: A. To bribe them to let her pass., B. To pay for their services., C. To distract them from her true intentions., D. To show her appreciation for their help. Correct Option: B
Question 7: What was the contents of the box given to Psyche by Proserpina? Options: A. A drop of beauty., B. A box of ambrosia., C. A box of sleep., D. A box of seeds. Correct Option: C
Question 8: What was the effect of the contents of the box on Psyche? Options: A. She became immortal., B. She fell in love with Cupid., C. She fell asleep., D. She became jealous of Cupid. Correct Option: C
Question 9: What did Cupid give to Psyche to make her immortal? Options: A. A drop of beauty., B. A box of ambrosia., C. A pinprick of his arrow., D. A gift from the gods. Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Consider the classic white t-shirt. Annually, we sell and buy
two billion t-shirts globally, making it one of the most common
garments in the world. But how and where is the average
t-shirt made, and what's its environmental impact? Clothing items can vary a lot, but a typical t-shirt begins its life
on a farm in America, China, or India where cotton seeds are sown, irrigated and
grown for the fluffy bolls they produce. Self-driving machines carefully harvest
these puffs, an industrial cotton gin mechanically
separates the fluffy bolls from the seeds, and the cotton lint is pressed 
into 225-kilogram bales. The cotton plants require a huge quantity
of water and pesticides. 2,700 liters of water are needed to produce
the average t-shirt, enough to fill more than 30 bathtubs. Meanwhile, cotton uses more insecticides
and pesticides than any other crop in the world. These pollutants can be carcinogenic, harm the health of field workers, and damage surrounding ecosystems. Some t-shirts are made of organic cotton
grown without pesticides and insecticides, but organic cotton makes up less than 1% of the 22.7 million metric tons 
of cotton produced worldwide. Once the cotton bales leave the farm, textile mills ship them
to a spinning facility, usually in China or India, where high-tech machines blend, card, comb, pull, stretch, and, finally, twist the cotton into
snowy ropes of yarn called slivers. Then, yarns are sent to the mill, where huge circular knitting machines weave them into sheets 
of rough grayish fabric treated with heat and chemicals
until they turn soft and white. Here, the fabric is dipped into
commercial bleaches and azo dyes, which make up the vivid coloring
in about 70% of textiles. Unfortunately, some of these contain
cancer-causing cadmium, lead, chromium, and mercury. Other harmful compounds and chemicals
can cause widespread contamination when released as toxic waste water
in rivers and oceans. Technologies are now so advanced
in some countries that the entire process of growing
and producing fabric barely touches a human hand. But only up until this point. After the finished cloth 
travels to factories, often in Bangladesh, China, India,
or Turkey, human labor is still required 
to stitch them up into t-shirts, intricate work that 
machines just can't do. This process has its own problems. Bangladesh, for example, which has surpassed China as the world's
biggest exporter of cotton t-shirts, employs 4.5 million people
in the t-shirt industry, but they typically face poor conditions
and low wages. After manufacture, all those t-shirts
travel by ship, train, and truck to be sold in high-income countries, a process that gives cotton 
an enormous carbon footprint. Some countries produce 
their own clothing domestically, which cuts out this polluting stage, but generally, apparel production accounts
for 10% of global carbon emissions. And it's escalating. Cheaper garments and the public's
willingness to buy boosted global production 
from 1994 to 2014 by 400% to around 80 billion garments each year. Finally, in a consumer's home, the t-shirt goes through one of the most
resource-intensive phases of its lifetime. In America, for instance, the average household does nearly
400 loads of laundry per year each using about 40 gallons of water. Washing machines and dryers 
both use energy, with dryers requiring five to six times
more than washers. This dramatic shift in clothing 
consumption over the last 20 years, driven by large corporations
and the trend of fast fashion has cost the environment, the health of farmers, and driven questionable 
human labor practices. It's also turned fashion into the second
largest polluter in the world after oil. But there are things we can do. Consider shopping secondhand. Try to look for textiles made from
recycled or organic fabrics. Wash clothes less and line dry
to save resources. Instead of throwing them away
at the end of their life, donate, recycle, or reuse them
as cleaning rags. And, finally, you might ask yourself, how many t-shirts and articles of clothing
will you consume over your lifetime, and what will be their combined 
impact on the world?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: To produce the average t-shirt takes:
Options: A. 225 kg of cotton, B. Large amounts of pesticides, C. 2700 liters of water, D. C only, E. Both B and C
Correct Option: E

To convince Proserpina to put a drop of her beauty in a box., D. To travel to the Underworld and collect a box from Proserpina. Correct Option: B

Question 5: What was the final task set by Venus for Psyche to complete? Options: A. To travel to the Underworld and convince Proserpina to put a drop of her beauty in a box., B. To sort a huge pile of seeds., C. To bring back the fleece of the golden sheep., D. To collect a box from Proserpina. Correct Option: A
Question 6: What was the purpose of the barley cakes and coins given to Cerberus and Charon by Psyche? Options: A. To bribe them to let her pass., B. To pay for their services., C. To distract them from her true intentions., D. To show her appreciation for their help. Correct Option: B
Question 7: What was the contents of the box given to Psyche by Proserpina? Options: A. A drop of beauty., B. A box of ambrosia., C. A box of sleep., D. A box of seeds. Correct Option: C

Correct Option: A

and the trend of fast fashion has cost the environment, the health of farmers, and driven questionable

largest polluter in the world after oil. But there are things we can do. Consider shopping secondhand. Try to look for textiles made from
recycled or organic fabrics. Wash clothes less and line dry
to save resources. Instead of throwing them away
at the end of their life, donate, recycle, or reuse them
as cleaning rags. And, finally, you might ask yourself, how many t-shirts and articles of clothing
will you consume over your lifetime, and what will be their combined 
impact on the world?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: After t-shirts are made and shipped to high income countries, often the ____ footprint of the item increases drastically.
Options: A. Cadmium, B. Cotton, C. Carbon, D. Lead
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:

To convince Proserpina to put a drop of her beauty in a box., D. To travel to the Underworld and collect a box from Proserpina. Correct Option: B

Question 5: What was the final task set by Venus for Psyche to complete? Options: A. To travel to the Underworld and convince Proserpina to put a drop of her beauty in a box., B. To sort a huge pile of seeds., C. To bring back the fleece of the golden sheep., D. To collect a box from Proserpina. Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 6
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Consider the classic white t-shirt. Annually, we sell and buy
two billion t-shirts globally, making it one of the most common
garments in the world. But how and where is the average
t-shirt made, and what's its environmental impact? Clothing items can vary a lot, but a typical t-shirt begins its life
on a farm in America, China, or India where cotton seeds are sown, irrigated and
grown for the fluffy bolls they produce. Self-driving machines carefully harvest
these puffs, an industrial cotton gin mechanically
separates the fluffy bolls from the seeds, and the cotton lint is pressed 
into 225-kilogram bales. The cotton plants require a huge quantity
of water and pesticides. 2,700 liters of water are needed to produce
the average t-shirt, enough to fill more than 30 bathtubs. Meanwhile, cotton uses more insecticides
and pesticides than any other crop in the world. These pollutants can be carcinogenic, harm the health of field workers, and damage surrounding ecosystems. Some t-shirts are made of organic cotton
grown without pesticides and insecticides, but organic cotton makes up less than 1% of the 22.7 million metric tons 
of cotton produced worldwide. Once the cotton bales leave the farm, textile mills ship them
to a spinning facility, usually in China or India, where high-tech machines blend, card, comb, pull, stretch, and, finally, twist the cotton into
snowy ropes of yarn called slivers. Then, yarns are sent to the mill, where huge circular knitting machines weave them into sheets 
of rough grayish fabric treated with heat and chemicals
until they turn soft and white. Here, the fabric is dipped into
commercial bleaches and azo dyes, which make up the vivid coloring
in about 70% of textiles. Unfortunately, some of these contain
cancer-causing cadmium, lead, chromium, and mercury. Other harmful compounds and chemicals
can cause widespread contamination when released as toxic waste water
in rivers and oceans. Technologies are now so advanced
in some countries that the entire process of growing
and producing fabric barely touches a human hand. But only up until this point. After the finished cloth 
travels to factories, often in Bangladesh, China, India,
or Turkey, human labor is still required 
to stitch them up into t-shirts, intricate work that 
machines just can't do. This process has its own problems. Bangladesh, for example, which has surpassed China as the world's
biggest exporter of cotton t-shirts, employs 4.5 million people
in the t-shirt industry, but they typically face poor conditions
and low wages. After manufacture, all those t-shirts
travel by ship, train, and truck to be sold in high-income countries, a process that gives cotton 
an enormous carbon footprint. Some countries produce 
their own clothing domestically, which cuts out this polluting stage, but generally, apparel production accounts
for 10% of global carbon emissions. And it's escalating. Cheaper garments and the public's
willingness to buy boosted global production 
from 1994 to 2014 by 400% to around 80 billion garments each year. Finally, in a consumer's home, the t-shirt goes through one of the most
resource-intensive phases of its lifetime. In America, for instance, the average household does nearly
400 loads of laundry per year each using about 40 gallons of water. Washing machines and dryers 
both use energy, with dryers requiring five to six times
more than washers. This dramatic shift in clothing 
consumption over the last 20 years, driven by large corporations
and the trend of fast fashion has cost the environment, the health of farmers, and driven questionable 
human labor practices. It's also turned fashion into the second
largest polluter in the world after oil. But there are things we can do. Consider shopping secondhand. Try to look for textiles made from
recycled or organic fabrics. Wash clothes less and line dry
to save resources. Instead of throwing them away
at the end of their life, donate, recycle, or reuse them
as cleaning rags. And, finally, you might ask yourself, how many t-shirts and articles of clothing
will you consume over your lifetime, and what will be their combined 
impact on the world?

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: If you decreased the amount of laundry loads in your household to 100 less than the average, how much water would you save per year?
Options: A. 200 gallons, B. 400 gallons, C. 600 gallons, D. 800 gallons
Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
"Beauty is a curse," Psyche thought as she looked over the cliff's edge
where she'd been abandoned by her father. She'd been born with the physical
perfection so complete that she was worshipped as a new
incarnation of Venus, the goddess of love. But real-life human lovers were
too intimidated even to approach her. When her father asked for guidance
from the Oracle of Apollo, the god of light, reason, and prophecy. He was told to abandon his daughter
on a rocky crag where she would marry a cruel
and savage serpent-like winged evil. Alone on the crag, Psyche felt
Zephyr the West Wind gently lifting her into the air. It set her down before a palace. "You are home," she heard 
an unseen voice say. "Your husband awaits you
in the bedroom, if you dare to meet him." She was brave enough, Psyche told herself. The bedroom was so dark that she
couldn't see her husband. But he didn't feel serpent-like at all. His skin was soft,
and his voice and manner were gentle. She asked him who he was, but he told her this was the one question
he could never answer. If she loved him, 
she would not need to know. His visits continued night after night. Before long, Psyche was pregnant. She rejoiced, but was also conflicted. How could she raise her baby
with a man she'd never seen? That night, Psyche approached
her sleeping husband holding an oil lamp. What she found was the god Cupid who sent gods and humans 
lusting after each other with the pinpricks of his arrows. Psyche dropped her lamp,
burning Cupid with hot oil. He said he'd been in love with Psyche
ever since his jealous mother, Venus, asked him to embarrass the young woman
by pricking her with an arrow. But taken with Psyche's beauty, Cupid
used the arrow on himself. He didn't believe, however, that gods
and humans could love as equals. Now that she knew his true form,
their hopes for happiness were dashed, so he flew away. Psyche was left in despair until
the unseen voice returned and told her that it was indeed possible for her and Cupid 
to love each other as equals. Encouraged, she set out to find him. But Venus intercepted Psyche and said
she and Cupid could only wed if she completed a series 
of impossible tasks. First, Psyche was told to sort a huge,
messy pile of seeds in a single night. Just as she was abandoning hope, an ant colony took pity on her
and helped with the work. Successfully passing the first trial, Psyche next had to bring Venus
the fleece of the golden sheep, who had a reputation for 
disemboweling stray adventurers, but a river god showed her how to collect the fleece the sheep 
had snagged on briars, and she succeeded. Finally, Psyche had to travel
to the Underworld and convince Proserpina, 
queen of the dead, to put a drop of her beauty in a box
for Venus. Once again, the unseen voice came
to Psyche's aide. It told her to bring barley cakes for
Cerberus, the guard dog to the Underworld and coins to pay the boatman, Charon
to ferry her across the river Styx. With her third and final task complete, Psyche returned to the land of the living. Just outside Venus's palace, she opened
the box of Proserpina's beauty, hoping to keep some for herself. But the box was filled with sleep,
not beauty, and Psyche collapsed in the road. Cupid, now recovered from his wounds,
flew to his sleeping bride. He told her he'd been wrong and foolish. Her fearlessness in the face
of the unknown proved that she was more than his equal. Cupid gave Psyche amborsia, the nectar
of the gods, making her immortal. Shortly after, Psyche bore their daughter. They named her Pleasure, and she, Cupid, and Psyche, 
whose name means soul, have been complicating people's
love lives ever since.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Cupid makes people fall in love with each other:
Options: A. By pricking them with an arrow, B. By setting them up on blind dates, C. By casting a spell, D. Though his mother Venus, goddess of love
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the main idea presented in the transcript about the left and right sides of the brain? Options: A. The left side of the brain controls logic and the right side controls creativity., B. The left and right sides of the brain control different body functions, but not logic and creativity., C. The brain's left and right sides are not essential for human function., D. The brain's left and right sides are identical in structure. Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is one theory for why we have a crossing over of visual fields in the brain? Options: A. It allows for better vision and more complex nervous systems., B. It allows for the brain to process information more efficiently., C. It is not known why we have a crossing over of visual fields., D. It allows for faster movement and quicker reflexes. Correct Option: D
Question 3: What was the misconception about the brain's left and right sides that began in the mid-1800s? Options: A. That the left side of the brain controls language and the right side controls movement., B. That the left side of the brain controls logic and the right side controls creativity., C. That the brain's left and right sides are identical in structure., D. That the brain's left and right sides are not essential for human function. Correct Option: B
Question 4: According to the transcript, what is one example of a function that is more localized to the left side of the brain? Options: A. Attention, B. Language, C. Movement, D. Vision Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the main idea presented in the transcript about the relationship between logic and creativity? Options: A. That logic and creativity are separate and distinct functions of the brain., B. That logic and creativity are at odds with each other., C. That logic and creativity are not related to the left and right sides of the brain., D. That logic and creativity are essential for human function. Correct Option: C
Question 6: According to the transcript, what is one example of a complex feat that requires both logic and creativity? Options: A. Solving a simple math problem, B. Creating a work of art, C. Solving a complex math problem, D. Creating a logical framework Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the main idea presented in the transcript about the brain's left and right sides? Options: A. That the brain's left and right sides are identical in constant conflict with each other., B. That the brain's left and right sides control different body functions., C. That the brain's left and right sides are identical in structure., D. That the brain's left and right sides are not essential for human function. Correct Option: B
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is one reason why some people may be more logical or creative? Options: A. It is due to genetics., B. It is due to environmental factors., C. It is due to the left and right sides of the brain., D. It is not known why some people may be more logical or creative. Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is the main idea presented in the transcript about the brain's left and right sides and human function? Options: A. That the brain's left and right sides are essential for human function., B. That the brain's left and right sides are not essential for human function., C. That the brain's left and right sides control different body functions., D. That the brain's left and right sides are identical in structure. Correct Option: C
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is one example of a logical framework that is present in a work of art? Options: A. A simple math problem, B. A complex math problem, C. A logical framework, D. A work of art without a logical framework Correct Option: C

by pricking her with an arrow. But taken with Psyche's beauty, Cupid
used the arrow on himself. He didn't believe, however, that gods
and humans could love as equals. Now that she knew his true form,
their hopes for happiness were dashed, so he flew away. Psyche was left in despair until
the unseen voice returned and told her that it was indeed possible for her and Cupid 
to love each other as equals. Encouraged, she set out to find him. But Venus intercepted Psyche and said
she and Cupid could only wed if she completed a series 
of impossible tasks. First, Psyche was told to sort a huge,
messy pile of seeds in a single night. Just as she was abandoning hope, an ant colony took pity on her
and helped with the work. Successfully passing the first trial, Psyche next had to bring Venus
the fleece of the golden sheep, who had a reputation for 
disemboweling stray adventurers, but a river god showed her how to collect the fleece the sheep 
had snagged on briars, and she succeeded. Finally, Psyche had to travel
to the Underworld and convince Proserpina, 
queen of the dead, to put a drop of her beauty in a box
for Venus. Once again, the unseen voice came
to Psyche's aide. It told her to bring barley cakes for
Cerberus, the guard dog to the Underworld and coins to pay the boatman, Charon
to ferry her across the river Styx. With her third and final task complete, Psyche returned to the land of the living. Just outside Venus's palace, she opened
the box of Proserpina's beauty, hoping to keep some for herself. But the box was filled with sleep,
not beauty, and Psyche collapsed in the road. Cupid, now recovered from his wounds,
flew to his sleeping bride. He told her he'd been wrong and foolish. Her fearlessness in the face
of the unknown proved that she was more than his equal. Cupid gave Psyche amborsia, the nectar
of the gods, making her immortal. Shortly after, Psyche bore their daughter. They named her Pleasure, and she, Cupid, and Psyche, 
whose name means soul, have been complicating people's
love lives ever since.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Venus is jealous of Psyche because:
Options: A. Cupid falls in love with Psyche, B. Psyche is brave, C. Psyche drinks ambrosia, becoming immortal like a god, D. Psyche steals beauty from the underworld, E. Psyche is so beautiful she attracts her own worshippers, like a god
Correct Option: E

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
"Beauty is a curse," Psyche thought as she looked over the cliff's edge
where she'd been abandoned by her father. She'd been born with the physical
perfection so complete that she was worshipped as a new
incarnation of Venus, the goddess of love. But real-life human lovers were
too intimidated even to approach her. When her father asked for guidance
from the Oracle of Apollo, the god of light, reason, and prophecy. He was told to abandon his daughter
on a rocky crag where she would marry a cruel
and savage serpent-like winged evil. Alone on the crag, Psyche felt
Zephyr the West Wind gently lifting her into the air. It set her down before a palace. "You are home," she heard 
an unseen voice say. "Your husband awaits you
in the bedroom, if you dare to meet him." She was brave enough, Psyche told herself. The bedroom was so dark that she
couldn't see her husband. But he didn't feel serpent-like at all. His skin was soft,
and his voice and manner were gentle. She asked him who he was, but he told her this was the one question
he could never answer. If she loved him, 
she would not need to know. His visits continued night after night. Before long, Psyche was pregnant. She rejoiced, but was also conflicted. How could she raise her baby
with a man she'd never seen? That night, Psyche approached
her sleeping husband holding an oil lamp. What she found was the god Cupid who sent gods and humans 
lusting after each other with the pinpricks of his arrows. Psyche dropped her lamp,
burning Cupid with hot oil. He said he'd been in love with Psyche
ever since his jealous mother, Venus, asked him to embarrass the young woman
by pricking her with an arrow. But taken with Psyche's beauty, Cupid
used the arrow on himself. He didn't believe, however, that gods
and humans could love as equals. Now that she knew his true form,
their hopes for happiness were dashed, so he flew away. Psyche was left in despair until
the unseen voice returned and told her that it was indeed possible for her and Cupid 
to love each other as equals. Encouraged, she set out to find him. But Venus intercepted Psyche and said
she and Cupid could only wed if she completed a series 
of impossible tasks. First, Psyche was told to sort a huge,
messy pile of seeds in a single night. Just as she was abandoning hope, an ant colony took pity on her
and helped with the work. Successfully passing the first trial, Psyche next had to bring Venus
the fleece of the golden sheep, who had a reputation for 
disemboweling stray adventurers, but a river god showed her how to collect the fleece the sheep 
had snagged on briars, and she succeeded. Finally, Psyche had to travel
to the Underworld and convince Proserpina, 
queen of the dead, to put a drop of her beauty in a box
for Venus. Once again, the unseen voice came
to Psyche's aide. It told her to bring barley cakes for
Cerberus, the guard dog to the Underworld and coins to pay the boatman, Charon
to ferry her across the river Styx. With her third and final task complete, Psyche returned to the land of the living. Just outside Venus's palace, she opened
the box of Proserpina's beauty, hoping to keep some for herself. But the box was filled with sleep,
not beauty, and Psyche collapsed in the road. Cupid, now recovered from his wounds,
flew to his sleeping bride. He told her he'd been wrong and foolish. Her fearlessness in the face
of the unknown proved that she was more than his equal. Cupid gave Psyche amborsia, the nectar
of the gods, making her immortal. Shortly after, Psyche bore their daughter. They named her Pleasure, and she, Cupid, and Psyche, 
whose name means soul, have been complicating people's
love lives ever since.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Behold the human brain, it's lumpy landscape visibly split into
a left and right side. This structure has inspired one of 
the most pervasive ideas about the brain, that the left side controls logic and the right, creativity. And yet, this is a myth unsupported
by scientific evidence. So how did this misleading idea
come about, and what does it get wrong? It's true that the brain has a right
and a left side. This is most apparent 
with the outer layer, or the cortex. Internal regions, like the striatum, hypothalamus, thalamus, and brain stem appear to be made from continuous tissue, but in fact, they're also organized
with left and right sides. The left and the right sides of the brain
do control different body functions, such as movement and sight. The brain's right side controls the motion
of the left arm and leg and vice versa. The visual system is even more complex. Each eye has a left 
and right visual field. Both left visual fields are sent
to the right side of the brain, and both right fields 
are sent to the left side. So the brain uses both sides to make
a complete image of the world. Scientists don't know for sure
why we have that crossing over. One theory is it began soon after animals
developed more complex nervous systems because it gave the survival advantage
of quicker reflexes. If an animal sees a predator coming
from its left side, it's best off escaping to the right. So we can say that vision 
and movement control are two systems that rely on this left-right structure, but problems arise when we over-extend
that idea to logic and creativity. This misconception began in 
the mid-1800s when two neurologists, Broca and Wernicke, examined patients who had problems
communicating due to injuries. The researchers found damage to
the patients' left temporal lobes, so they suggested that language is
controlled by the left side of the brain. That captured the popular imagination. Author Robert Louis Stevenson then introduced the idea 
of a logical left hemisphere competing with an emotional 
right hemisphere represented by his characters
Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde. But this idea didn't hold up when doctors
and scientists examined patients who were missing
a hemisphere or had their two hemispheres separated. These patients showed a complete
range of behaviors, both logical and creative. Later research showed that one side
of the brain is more active than the other for some functions. Language is more localized to the left and attention to the right. So one side of the brain may do more work, but this varies by system
rather than by person. There isn't any evidence to suggest that individuals have dominant 
sides of the brain, or to support the idea 
of a left-right split between logic and creativity. Some people may be particularly logical
or creative, but that has nothing to do with the sides
of their brains. And even the idea of logic and creativity
being at odds with each other doesn't hold up well. Solving complex math problems requires
inspired creativity and many vibrant works of art
have intricate logical frameworks. Almost every feat of creativity and logic carries the mark of the whole brain
functioning as one.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which statement below is a myth?
Options: A. The human brain is clearly divided into two parts, B. The left side of the brain controls logic, and the right controls creativity, C. The outer layer of the brain is called the cortex, D. Both a and b are myths
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the approximate weight of caffeine consumed around the world every year? Options: A. 10,000 metric tons, B. 50,000 metric tons, C. 100,000 metric tons, D. 200,000 metric tons Correct Option: C
Question 2: What is the primary function of caffeine in plants? Options: A. To attract insects, B. To repel insects, C. To help insects remember and revisit flowers, D. To produce flowers Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the effect of adenosine on neurons in the brain? Options: A. It stimulates neurons to fire more quickly, B. It has no effect on neurons, C. It slows the release of brain-signaling molecules and causes neurons to fire more sluggishly, D. It increases the production of dopamine Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the role of dopamine in the brain? Options: A. To promote feelings of anxiety, B. To promote feelings of pleasure, C. To regulate blood pressure, D. To regulate body temperature Correct Option: B
Question 5: What is the effect of caffeine on dopamine receptors in the brain? Options: A. It reduces the release of dopamine, B. It has no effect on dopamine receptors, C. It allows dopamine to fit into its receptor more easily, D. It blocks the action of dopamine Correct Option: C
Question 6: What are some potential long-term benefits of caffeine consumption? Options: A. Reduced risk of heart disease and stroke, B. Reduced risk of Parkinson's, Alzheimer's, and some types of cancer, C. Improved cognitive function and memory, D. All of the above Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the effect of caffeine on the body's ability to burn fat? Options: A. It reduces the body's ability to burn fat, B. It has no effect on the body's ability to burn fat, C. It increases the body's ability to burn fat, D. It decreases the body's ability to burn fat Correct Option: C
Question 8: Why do some sports organizations place limits on caffeine consumption? Options: A. Because caffeine is a banned substance, B. Because caffeine gives athletes an unfair advantage, C. Because caffeine is a performance-enhancing substance, D. Because caffeine is a stimulant Correct Option: B
Question 9: What happens to the body when caffeine consumption is stopped suddenly? Options: A. The body adapts quickly to the absence of caffeine, B. The body experiences no withdrawal symptoms, C. The body experiences withdrawal symptoms such as headaches and fatigue, D. The body becomes dependent on caffeine Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the long-term effect of caffeine consumption on the body's adenosine receptors? Options: A. The number of adenosine receptors increases, B. The number of adenosine receptors decreases, C. The number of adenosine receptors remains the same, D. The body adapts to the presence of caffeine Correct Option: A
Question 11: What is the approximate blood-caffeine concentration limit for Olympic athletes? Options: A. 0.1 mg/mL, B. 0.5 mg/mL, C. 1.0 mg/mL, D. 2.0 mg/mL Correct Option: B
Question 12: What is the effect of caffeine on the body's ability to regulate blood pressure? Options: A. It lowers blood pressure, B. It has no effect on blood pressure, C. It raises blood pressure, D. It decreases blood pressure Correct Option: C
Question 13: What is the potential impact of caffeine consumption on the risk of certain diseases? Options: A. It increases the risk of Parkinson's, Alzheimer's, and some types of cancer, B. It has no effect on the risk of these diseases, C. It reduces the risk of Parkinson's, Alzheimer's, and some types of cancer, D. It increases the risk of heart disease and stroke Correct Option: C
Question 14: What is the effect of caffeine on the body's ability to regulate body temperature? Options: A. It lowers body temperature, B. It has no effect on body temperature, C. It raises body temperature, D. It decreases body temperature Correct Option: B
Question 15: What is the potential impact of caffeine consumption on the body's ability to regulate sleep? Options: A. It improves sleep quality, B. It has no effect on sleep quality, C. It disrupts sleep patterns, D. It increases sleep duration Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 11, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Behold the human brain, it's lumpy landscape visibly split into
a left and right side. This structure has inspired one of 
the most pervasive ideas about the brain, that the left side controls logic and the right, creativity. And yet, this is a myth unsupported
by scientific evidence. So how did this misleading idea
come about, and what does it get wrong? It's true that the brain has a right
and a left side. This is most apparent 
with the outer layer, or the cortex. Internal regions, like the striatum, hypothalamus, thalamus, and brain stem appear to be made from continuous tissue, but in fact, they're also organized
with left and right sides. The left and the right sides of the brain
do control different body functions, such as movement and sight. The brain's right side controls the motion
of the left arm and leg and vice versa. The visual system is even more complex. Each eye has a left 
and right visual field. Both left visual fields are sent
to the right side of the brain, and both right fields 
are sent to the left side. So the brain uses both sides to make
a complete image of the world. Scientists don't know for sure
why we have that crossing over. One theory is it began soon after animals
developed more complex nervous systems because it gave the survival advantage
of quicker reflexes. If an animal sees a predator coming
from its left side, it's best off escaping to the right. So we can say that vision 
and movement control are two systems that rely on this left-right structure, but problems arise when we over-extend
that idea to logic and creativity. This misconception began in 
the mid-1800s when two neurologists, Broca and Wernicke, examined patients who had problems
communicating due to injuries. The researchers found damage to
the patients' left temporal lobes, so they suggested that language is
controlled by the left side of the brain. That captured the popular imagination. Author Robert Louis Stevenson then introduced the idea 
of a logical left hemisphere competing with an emotional 
right hemisphere represented by his characters
Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde. But this idea didn't hold up when doctors
and scientists examined patients who were missing
a hemisphere or had their two hemispheres separated. These patients showed a complete
range of behaviors, both logical and creative. Later research showed that one side
of the brain is more active than the other for some functions. Language is more localized to the left and attention to the right. So one side of the brain may do more work, but this varies by system
rather than by person. There isn't any evidence to suggest that individuals have dominant 
sides of the brain, or to support the idea 
of a left-right split between logic and creativity. Some people may be particularly logical
or creative, but that has nothing to do with the sides
of their brains. And even the idea of logic and creativity
being at odds with each other doesn't hold up well. Solving complex math problems requires
inspired creativity and many vibrant works of art
have intricate logical frameworks. Almost every feat of creativity and logic carries the mark of the whole brain
functioning as one.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The right side of the brain controls the movement of the:
Options: A. Right side arm and leg, B. Left side arm and leg, C. Both arms and legs, D. The eyes
Correct Option: B

Question 3: What is the effect of adenosine on neurons in the brain? Options: A. It stimulates neurons to fire more quickly, B. It has no effect on neurons, C. It slows the release of brain-signaling molecules and causes neurons to fire more sluggishly, D. It increases the production of dopamine Correct Option: C

Question 12: What is the effect of caffeine on the body's ability to regulate blood pressure? Options: A. It lowers blood pressure, B. It has no effect on blood pressure, C. It raises blood pressure, D. It decreases blood pressure Correct Option: C
Question 13: What is the potential impact of caffeine consumption on the risk of certain diseases? Options: A. It increases the risk of Parkinson's, Alzheimer's, and some types of cancer, B. It has no effect on the risk of these diseases, C. It reduces the risk of Parkinson's, Alzheimer's, and some types of cancer, D. It increases the risk of heart disease and stroke Correct Option: C
Question 14: What is the effect of caffeine on the body's ability to regulate body temperature? Options: A. It lowers body temperature, B. It has no effect on body temperature, C. It raises body temperature, D. It decreases body temperature Correct Option: B
Question 15: What is the potential impact of caffeine consumption on the body's ability to regulate sleep? Options: A. It improves sleep quality, B. It has no effect on sleep quality, C. It disrupts sleep patterns, D. It increases sleep duration Correct Option: C
